job_title: Case Manager in San Mateo, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Mateo, CA
pros: Love the challenge of helping some of the most difficult clients in San Mateo County. Solid and supportive, colleagues and management. This is the most supportive work culture that I have worked in. Professional development, solid COVID safety protocols have kept everyone safe throughout the pandemic. I’m not planning on going anywhere.
cons: This is a job that demands heart and a passion to serve, grit to handle difficult clients, organization skills for heavy and diverse tasks and the ability to rapidly pivot to prioritize clients in crisis and unforeseen problems. For the right person, this is a great opportunity to blossom. For someone just looking for a paycheck, it’s a good way to get thrashed and burnt out.

job_title: Clinical Supervisor in San Jose, CA
pros: Great management team, very supportive, caring group of people to work with and work for.
cons: Lots of paperwork at every level, EHR not easy to navigate.

job_title: Administrative in San Mateo, CA
pros: Great team of caring, compassionate individuals. Inspiring client success stories. Truly awe-inspiring work happening.
cons: More staff needed in certain roles and teams, but funding prevents extra hiring. Nonprofit burn out can be high no matter where you go, though. Not a surprising con.

review_title: Good group of engineers that seem to care
job_title: Project Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Worked with various teams to achieve project goals. Walked away with a feeling of accomplishment and a genuine feeling that we contributed to a larger cause.
cons: Growing company, wish they could extend help into other communities.

job_title: Case Manager in Jersey City, NJ

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Newark, NJ

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Free lunch, good work culture, supportive environment, caring staff, fulfilling work, enjoyable colleagues, highly recommend to seek employment here, supervisors are supportive and understanding
cons: I do not have any cons that I can think of working at Caminar. This is why I still work at this job.

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: The clients are the reason I stay.
cons: Case notes and paperwork is overwhelming.

job_title: Residential Counselor in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Love the people, and the work done
cons: Understaffed, underpaid, everyone is burnt out

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros:
I have worked in many agencies in a supervisory roles before coming to Caminar and can empathize with the unfortunate , unrealistic and challenging predicaments management and line staff are often placed in.

I believe the program directors, current and former, specifically AOT, REACH, and REACH/FSP have huge boots to fill and do their best to support their staff and provide both guidance and structure to support their professional growth. They not only have to complete the day to day managerial tasks that come along with the position but they also have to support their team (2 Assistant Case Manager's, 5 Case Manager's, 50+ client consumers per team) who are working DAILY to meet the needs of our county's most high at-risk consumers.

Compared to most non-profits, Caminar pays their case managers extremely well , provides weekly (often daily) supervision for their staff and encourages their ever growing education in the field.
cons:
Smaller Caseload Sizes (but understand it is typically part of the contract each program holds that dictates the case load...not management)

Better Food Truck Selection

job_title: Job Developer in San Mateo, CA
pros: This is a magical company!!!  At the moment, the organization seems very well run; they have upper management in place who are top notch.  The company appears to be heading in a great direction.  I have hardly been in such a supportive workplace environment.  Someone at the top has done something right.  They are fundraising extremely well, there are innovative, out-side-of-the-box employees in development who are doing things that other non-profits simply are not doing: holding major fundraising gala's at the SF Jazz festival raising hundreds of thousands of dollars, continuing to market other company-wide events.  Also, Caminar is great about holding staff appreciation and client appreciation events.  It is a great time to come to Caminar!!!
cons: The pay could go up for most positions, but that is the case with most non-profits.  Actually, Caminar is pretty good in the compensation department comparatively.  There are some upfront costs involved, such as use of personal vehicle and phone

review_title: A Company that's Lost Their Humanistic Approach
job_title: Administrative in Redwood City, CA
pros:
The clients appreciate the staff and case managers which makes it worth staying.
The clients show the case managers by working on their sobriety, obtaining employment, and finding housing once medication stabilized.
cons:
The company picks negative attributes in their employees and focuses on them.
They never focus on their employees positive attributes than wonder why there's such bad rapport.
The company has lost valuable intelligent employees because of the way they are treated.
They will say if you don't like it find another job.
Employees care about those clients and when getting into human services walking away isn't so easy.

job_title: Case Manager in Vallejo, CA
pros: The clients, coworkers, clinical supervision.
cons: This agency is not what it used to be. Major changes in upper management, complete disconnect with "frontline" case managers. Under trained/incompetent supervisor in the REACH program with no clinical or therapeutic knowledge. They exploit their employees with unrealistic expectations and workload. Employees are expected to work overtime without compensation and reprimanded if they don't complete work or ask for support. Instead of asking questions and finding solutions to support case managers , management brings in HR to provide a "pep talk" that this work is simple and all case managers need to do is see clients, write timely notes, and return phone calls. Management thinks "change" is normal and does not question why there is such a high turnover rate. If you want to feel underpaid, under valued, demoralized and overworked, this place is for you.

job_title: Job Coach in Vallejo, CA
pros: You get to help a lot of people with all sorts of disorders, whether it's mental or physical. It's for people who can connect with those who have these disorders. In addition, you get to make a lot of friends with your co-workers, because they are all wonderful.
cons: Not everyone is easy to assist through both clerical and retail assessments, but it takes a lot of patience and time to make sure they can succeed. That's what this job taught me.

job_title: Case Manager in San Mateo, CA
pros: supportive managers, by the time ended there management had attempted to build better work culture (i.e. food trucks, holiday party at Levi's), good work resources (i.e. laptop, tablets, wireless networks to do notes in the field)
cons: Having to work the emergency line (mandatory on rotating basis), was extremely stressful having to transport clients to/back appointments if they didn't have transportation

review_title: Unprofessional and unethical management for REACH/FSP
job_title: Clinical Case Manager in San Mateo, CA
pros: Free lunches every other Wednesday
cons: Poor management in the REACH and FSP team. They promote a hostile work environment as well promote that co-workers should report on each other. The Program directors of FSP and Reach don’t want  don’t want gossip among the other employees but then want to you tell them about what other employees said. Poor boundaries. Lack of training for the job. Confusion around scheduling. Feeling disrespected and not feeling see and heard.

review_title: Make the most of your time there
job_title: Clinical Case Manager in San Mateo, CA
pros: Pay, company cars to transport clients or go out into the community, autonomy, clinical exposure, opportunity to work in conjunction with med clinic/nurses/psychiatric NP's/psychiatrists.
cons: High turnover, unprofessional behavior of some staff

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Mateo, CA
pros: There are great people who work there and opportunities to work with the San Mateo community. Good wages and benefits.
cons: Very high turnover rate and poor communication between teams and upper management. A lot of politics and drama that damage morale and make it difficult to focus on job tasks.

job_title: Case Manager in Vallejo, CA
pros: Dedicated staff with an amazing mission. Lots of training opportunities and supervision for all line staff.
cons: Too much reliance on contracts makes raises obsolete. Poor pay makes staff turnover inevitable.

job_title: Case Manager in Vallejo, CA
